study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different synbiotic processing methods on intestinal bacterial count, morphology, and histological status in male Mandarah chicks.
results_summary: Synbiotics administered via drinking water (0.25 or 0.50 mL) significantly increased lactic acid bacteria and reduced Escherichia coli concentrations. Treated chicks also showed improved duodenum and ileum villus height and crypt depth ratios compared to controls.
population_specificity: Male Mandarah line chicks aged 1 day.
effective_dosage: 0.25 mL or 0.50 mL administered once via spray, drinking water, or oral drops.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of probiotics or synbiotics on cardiovascular factors in adults with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that probiotics or synbiotics reduced BMI, LDL-c, and fasting blood glucose in MetS patients but showed no significant effect on systolic blood pressure.
population_specificity: Adults with metabolic syndrome (MetS)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of synbiotics on liver steatosis, inflammation, and stool microbiome in patients with Metabolic Dysfunction-associated Liver Disease (MASLD).
results_summary: Synbiotics significantly reduced liver steatosis, decreased high-sensitive C-reactive protein levels, enriched beneficial gut bacteria (Lactobacillus, Bifidobacterium, Faecalibacterium, Streptococcus), reduced harmful bacteria (Ruminococcus, Enterobacterium), and shortened gut transition time.
population_specificity: 84 MASLD patients with specific elastometric attenuation coefficient and alanine aminotransferase level criteria.
effective_dosage: 64x10^9 CFU of Lactobacillus and Bifidobacterium plus 6.4g of inulin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the efficacy of probiotics and/or synbiotics in treating gestational diabetes mellitus by targeting insulin resistance, lipid metabolism, and anti-inflammatory effects.
results_summary: Probiotic and synbiotic supplementation significantly reduced insulin resistance, improved glycemic control, blood lipid profiles, and inflammation in women with gestational diabetes mellitus. The study found statistically significant reductions in fasting blood glucose, insulin levels, triglycerides, and C-reactive protein.
population_specificity: Women with gestational diabetes mellitus (896 patients across 13 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the mechanistic overview, therapeutic potential, and health benefits of synbiotics in modulating gut microbiota and improving metabolic health.
results_summary: Synbiotics show promise in stabilizing gut microbiota and improving metabolic health, potentially serving as effective therapeutic agents for chronic diseases. However, optimal combinations, dosages, and safety profiles require further clinical investigation.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health focus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of probiotic and synbiotic supplementation on clinical outcomes in critically ill patients, focusing on ventilator-associated pneumonia, sepsis, and other secondary measures.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics significantly reduced the incidence of ventilator-associated pneumonia and sepsis, as well as decreased ICU mortality, length of ICU stay, and hospital stay. No significant effects were observed for diarrhea, CDI, hospital-acquired pneumonia, or in-hospital mortality.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients (4,065 in the treatment group, 3,821 in the control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of synbiotic FamiLact 2plus on preventing ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) in ICU patients.
results_summary: The synbiotic group had a lower incidence of VAP (10% vs. 27.5%), shorter ICU stays, and delayed VAP onset compared to placebo. Diarrhea incidence was also significantly lower in the synbiotic group (37.5% vs. 65%).
population_specificity: Mechanically ventilated patients admitted to the intensive care unit (ICU).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether synbiotics, as an adjunctive therapy, could improve outcomes in patients with persistent allergic rhinitis (PAR) when added to standard treatment.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics supplementation significantly reduced IgE levels compared to placebo and showed positive effects on symptomology, particularly in activity variables, ocular symptoms, and practical problems, though nasal symptom improvements were observed in both groups.
population_specificity: Thirty patients with persistent allergic rhinitis (PAR).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the combination of Sonchus brachyotus DC. extracts and synbiotics is more effective in preventing and treating NAFLD compared to using either component alone.
results_summary: The study found that the combination of Sonchus brachyotus DC. extracts and synbiotics was significantly more effective in improving NAFLD-related indicators and glucolipid metabolism than isolated use of either component. The synergy showed potential as a novel therapeutic approach for NAFLD.
population_specificity: Preclinical animal model (specific species not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of probiotics and synbiotics in treating childhood functional constipation.
results_summary: Synbiotics plus laxatives showed no significant effect on defecation frequency or painful defecation compared to laxatives alone. The study concluded that current evidence does not support the use of synbiotics for childhood functional constipation.
population_specificity: Children diagnosed with functional constipation using Rome III/IV criteria.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to comprehensively evaluate the effects of gut microbial therapy (including synbiotics) on inflammatory markers in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: Synbiotics significantly reduced serum C-reactive protein (CRP) and tumor necrosis factor-a (TNF-a) levels in NAFLD patients, with strong statistical significance (P < 0.001). The effect sizes were moderate to large, particularly for TNF-a reduction (ES: -0.96).
population_specificity: Patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of probiotics or synbiotics on risk factors for coronary artery disease (CAD) when used alongside conventional CAD medications.
results_summary: The study found that adding probiotics or synbiotics to conventional CAD medications improved several risk factors, including reducing LDL cholesterol, fasting glucose, and hs-CRP levels while increasing HDL cholesterol and nitric oxide levels, but did not significantly affect triglycerides or blood pressure.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary artery disease (CAD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether synbiotics supplementation could safely and effectively reduce common chemotherapy side effects in women with breast cancer.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics significantly reduced the severity of fatigue and abnormal defecation, and showed potential in reducing anorexia and nausea/vomiting, though the latter effects were not statistically significant compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 67 women with a definitive diagnosis of breast cancer undergoing chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Oral consumption of synbiotics supplements twice a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of synbiotics in managing ulcerative colitis (UC) by modulating oxidative stress, gut microbiota, and inflammatory responses.
results_summary: Synbiotics were found to alleviate colon inflammation by reducing reactive oxygen species (ROS) and enhancing antioxidant enzyme levels (CAT, GPX, SOD). The study highlights favorable outcomes for UC management with synbiotics, though fewer studies exist on their combined use with prebiotics.
population_specificity: Patients with ulcerative colitis (UC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a synbiotic product (PROBIOPlus™) on maintaining gastrointestinal microbiome health in horses receiving antibiotics.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics (PBP + AB) led to significant differences in microbiota community membership compared to other treatments, particularly during and after antibiotic administration, with notable effects on fiber-degrading bacteria like Fibrobacter and Ruminococcaceae. The results suggest PROBIOPlus™ may help maintain a healthy microbiome during antibiotic use.
population_specificity: Actively racing Standardbred horses

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effects of microbiome-targeted therapies, including synbiotics, on liver-related outcomes in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics significantly improved liver steatosis, fibrosis, and liver enzyme levels (ALT, AST, GGT) in NAFLD patients, though heterogeneity in probiotic strains and formulations was noted as a limitation.
population_specificity: Patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of an innovative synbiotic in modulating gut microbiota and metabolome in stage IIIb-IV CKD patients.
results_summary: The study found significant changes in microbiota profile and increased saccharolytic metabolism in feces for CKD patients receiving synbiotics, indicating selective efficacy in this population.
population_specificity: Stage IIIb-IV chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients and healthy controls.
study_duration: 2 months of treatment, followed by 1 month of washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically investigate the therapeutic effect of synbiotic supplementation on patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: Synbiotic supplementation significantly improved liver function markers (ALT, AST, GGT), adjusted lipid metabolism (reduced total cholesterol and LDL, increased HDL), and reduced liver fibrosis indicators (LSM and CAP) in NAFLD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) (634 participants across 10 randomized controlled trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of prebiotics, probiotics, and synbiotics supplementation in patients with primary thyroid diseases, particularly hypothyroidism.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of two RCTs showed no clinically or statistically significant changes in TSH or fT3 levels, with only constipation scores improving significantly. Low-certainty evidence suggests little to no benefit from routine administration of these supplements in hypothyroid patients.
population_specificity: 136 hypothyroid participants

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of synbiotics, along with prebiotics and probiotics, on improving symptoms of depression in patients.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics, prebiotics, and probiotics significantly improved depressive symptoms compared to placebo, though subgroup analysis confirmed significant effects only for probiotic-containing agents. Patients with mild or moderate depression benefited from the treatment, with stronger effects observed in studies with a lower proportion of females.
population_specificity: Patients with mild or moderate depression (786 participants across 13 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of probiotics, prebiotics, and synbiotics in improving bowel function post-operatively in patients who underwent abdominal surgery.
results_summary: Synbiotics reduced the time to first flatus and post-operative hospitalization days compared to placebo/no intervention. Probiotics also showed benefits in reducing post-operative ileus, time to first flatus, time to first defecation, and abdominal distension.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent abdominal surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the anti-inflammatory effects of endogenous and exogenous L. plantarum combined with chitosan oligosaccharides (COS) as synbiotics in alleviating DSS-induced colitis in mice.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics (L. plantarum + COS) alleviated colitis symptoms, improved gut microbiota composition, and modulated inflammatory markers more effectively than L. plantarum alone, with exogenous synbiotics showing superior effects.
population_specificity: DSS-induced acute colitis mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify gut microbiota species involved in adverse events during neoadjuvant chemotherapy (NAC) and assess their influence on the efficacy of synbiotic therapy (LBG+EN) in oesophageal cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that higher abundances of Anaerostipes hadrus and Bifidobacterium pseudocatenulatum were associated with reduced febrile neutropenia and diarrhoea. LBG+EN efficacy was linked to pre-NAC A. hadrus levels, suggesting its potential as a predictive biomarker for therapy response.
population_specificity: 73 oesophageal cancer patients receiving neoadjuvant chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and mechanistic effects of probiotics, prebiotics, and synbiotics in treating nonalcoholic fatty liver disease and alcohol-associated liver disease.
results_summary: The study highlights that synbiotics modulate gut microbiota, restore a healthy microbiome, and show promise as a treatment option for chronic liver diseases by targeting disrupted intestinal barriers and altered metabolomes.
population_specificity: Patients with nonalcoholic fatty liver disease and alcohol-associated liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of synbiotics in mitigating chemotherapy-associated side effects by restoring gut microbiota in cancer patients.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that synbiotics may offer better health benefits compared to probiotics alone in restoring gut microbiota and reducing chemotherapy-related complications, though no specific outcomes or statistical results are detailed.
population_specificity: Cancer patients receiving chemotherapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effectiveness of prebiotics, probiotics, and synbiotics in managing inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), focusing on their role in restoring gut microflora balance and reducing inflammation.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics, along with prebiotics and probiotics, show promise in suppressing inflammation, inducing remission, and preventing relapse in IBD with minimal side effects, though clinical trial results were sometimes conflicting.
population_specificity: Patients with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis/pouchitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the effects of antibiotic-induced gut dysbiosis and discuss the potential of probiotics, fermented foods, or synbiotic supplements to restore gut microbiota balance.
results_summary: The abstract highlights that antibiotic therapy can disrupt gut microbiota, leading to health issues, and suggests that introducing probiotics or synbiotics may help restore balance and improve gut-brain health.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion on gut dysbiosis and potential interventions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of probiotics/synbiotics on glucose and lipid metabolism in women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).
results_summary: Probiotics/synbiotics significantly improved fasting plasma glucose, fasting serum insulin, HOMA-IR, and total cholesterol in women with GDM, though other metabolic indicators showed no significant difference. The study suggests that specific probiotic supplementation may be a promising strategy for GDM management.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether synbiotics (a combination of prebiotics and probiotics) could improve adipose tissue metabolism and prevent alcoholic liver disease (ALD) by modulating inflammation and oxidative stress.
results_summary: Synbiotics maintained adipocyte morphology, upregulated adiponectin, downregulated inflammatory markers (leptin, resistin, PPARγ, CYP2E1, iNOS, IL-6, TNF-α), and reduced oxidative stress in adipose tissue, suggesting a protective effect against ALD. In-silico analysis indicated that aged garlic extract (AGE) inhibited key pathways, with PPARγ as a primary target.
population_specificity: In vitro (3T3-L1 cells) and in vivo (Wistar male rats) models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a synbiotic combination of a high-prebiotic diet and probiotic supplements could improve mental health outcomes in adults with moderate psychological distress and low prebiotic intake.
results_summary: The study found no evidence of symptom improvement from the synbiotic treatment, with no benefit observed for mood, anxiety, stress, or sleep. The synbiotic combination did not outperform placebo in any mental health outcome measure.
population_specificity: Adults with moderate psychological distress and low prebiotic food intake (n=119).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy and safety of synbiotics in reducing gastrointestinal toxicity and improving quality of life in patients undergoing auto-HSCT for malignant lymphoma.
results_summary: The study found that synbiotics reduced the duration of severe diarrhea, shortened hospital stays, and improved oral intake and quality of life post-engraftment, without causing severe adverse events like bacteremia.
population_specificity: Patients with malignant lymphoma eligible for autologous hematopoietic stem cell transplantation (auto-HSCT).
effective_dosage: Bifidobacterium longum (BB536) and guar gum, administered twice daily.
study_duration: From the start of conditioning chemotherapy up to 28 days after auto-HSCT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of synbiotics (a combination of Bifidobacterium breve MCC1274 and lactulose) on gut microbiota composition and metabolite production compared to probiotics or prebiotics alone.
results_summary: The synbiotic group showed a significant increase in Bifidobacterium abundance and produced the highest number of metabolites, including enriched tryptophan metabolites and polyamines, suggesting enhanced signaling molecule production in the gut. The effects were attributed to interactions between the probiotic strain and fecal microbiota.
population_specificity: Human gut microbiota model (fecal fermentation system).

study_goal: To determine if long-term synbiotic supplementation improves clinical, endocrine, and metabolic aspects of PCOS in overweight and obese individuals undergoing lifestyle modifications.
results_summary: Synbiotic supplementation significantly reduced total testosterone, LH, cholesterol, LDL, triglycerides, LPS, and LPS-binding protein compared to placebo, while both groups showed comparable BMI and body fat reductions.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese individuals with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of synbiotics on metabolic syndrome components and related biomarkers in patients with schizophrenia receiving antipsychotic drugs.
results_summary: The synbiotic supplement significantly reduced waist circumference and HbA1c, prevented BMI increase, and lowered LDL-c and triglyceride levels, though some metabolic parameters showed no significant difference compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Seventy patients with schizophrenia receiving antipsychotic drugs and meeting at least two criteria for metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: Two capsules of synbiotic supplement daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of synbiotics on liver enzymes, blood pressure, inflammation, and lipid profiles in patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that synbiotics significantly improved liver enzymes (AST, ALT, GGT), lipid profile (TC), obesity indices (body weight, WC), systolic blood pressure (SBP), and inflammatory markers (CRP, TNF-α) in NAFLD patients.
population_specificity: Patients with non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the immunomodulatory effects of synbiotics in healthy adults.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of synbiotics.
population_specificity: 106 healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of synbiotics and an anti-inflammatory-antioxidant-rich diet on fatigue, pain, gut/bladder status, and sexual function in patients with progressive forms of multiple sclerosis.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in fatigue, pain, bladder and bowel control, and sexual function in the experimental group compared to the control group, with no serious side effects reported. The adherence rate was high (98%), and outcomes were statistically significant.
population_specificity: Patients with progressive forms of multiple sclerosis (primary-progressive, secondary-progressive, and progressive-relapsing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of synbiotics on health-related quality of life (HRQoL) in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS).
results_summary: Synbiotic supplementation significantly improved emotional, body hair, weight, and infertility domains of PCOSQ-26 and the physical score of SF-12, but no significant improvement was seen in perceived stress (PSS-10).
population_specificity: Women with PCOS (n=52 completed the trial).
effective_dosage: Daily 2-gram synbiotic sachets (containing Bacillus coagulans (GBI-30), Lactobacillus rhamnosus, Lactobacillus helveticus, and fructooligosaccharide).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantitatively summarize and analyze the effects of pro/pre/synbiotics on lipid profiles in diabetic individuals to assess their potential in ameliorating dyslipidemia and reducing cardiovascular disease risk.
results_summary: The study found that pro/pre/synbiotics significantly improved lipid profiles, including reductions in total cholesterol, LDL, VLDL, and triglycerides, and an increase in HDL. These effects were influenced by patient and intervention characteristics, though inter-study heterogeneity and unknown confounders limit clinical adoption.
population_specificity: Diabetic individuals (n = 2692 across 42 studies)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of stachyose (ST) and Latilactobacillus sakei Furu 2019 (L. sakei), alone or combined, on diphenoxylate-induced constipation in mice and explore the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that ST, L. sakei, and their synbiotic combination alleviated constipation, with the synbiotic intervention showing superior effects in some defecation indicators. The interventions worked by affecting aquaporins, interstitial cells of Cajal, neurotrophic factors, neurotransmitters, and gut microbiota, increasing beneficial bacteria like Akkermansia.
population_specificity: ICR mice with diphenoxylate-induced constipation.
effective_dosage: ST (1.5 g/kg body weight), L. sakei (3 × 10^9 CFU/mouse), or ST + L. sakei (1.5 g/kg plus 3 × 10^9 CFU/mouse).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of pro-/synbiotic supplementation on brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) levels through a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of 10 RCTs involving 652 participants found that pro-/synbiotic supplementation significantly increased BDNF concentrations compared to placebo, with a weighted mean difference of 0.20 ng/mL. However, the abstract notes that human study results on this topic have been inconsistent and conflicting.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human population, based on included RCTs)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of synbiotic supplementation on enteral feed volume, energy-protein homeostasis, and muscle mass maintenance in critically ill adult patients.
results_summary: Synbiotic supplementation increased enteral feed volume, energy, and protein intake during the first 4 days but showed no statistically significant effect on energy-protein homeostasis or muscle mass maintenance by day 14. Mid-arm circumference and creatinine-related markers remained stable in the synbiotic group but declined in the placebo group.
population_specificity: Critically ill adult patients admitted to a medical ICU requiring enteral nutrition.
effective_dosage: Not specified (synbiotic capsule containing Lactobacillus, Bifidobacterium, Streptococcus, and fructooligosaccharides).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of synbiotic supplementation on lipid and glucose homeostasis in tube-fed critically ill adult patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in fasting glucose, insulin, HOMA-IR, total cholesterol, triglycerides, or free fatty acids after synbiotic supplementation compared to placebo. The decreases observed were not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Tube-fed critically ill adult patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether synbiotic supplementation affects the IL-17/IL-23 pathway and disease activity in axial spondyloarthritis (axSpA) patients.
results_summary: Synbiotic supplementation significantly reduced IL17-expressing CD4+ T cells and IL-17/IL-23 pathway markers but did not improve disease activity scores (BASDAI, ASDAS-CRP).
population_specificity: 48 axSpA patients, with 38 completing the study.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of synbiotic supplementation combined with a low-calorie diet on recurrence-related factors (adiponectin, TNF-α, and hs-CRP) in overweight and obese postmenopausal breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: Synbiotic intake significantly increased adiponectin levels and significantly reduced TNF-α and hs-CRP levels compared to placebo, indicating beneficial effects on these recurrence-related factors.
population_specificity: Overweight or obese postmenopausal women with a history of hormone-receptor-positive breast cancer.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of synbiotic supplementation combined with calorie restriction on quality of life and edema volume in overweight and obese women with breast cancer-related lymphedema (BCRL).
results_summary: Synbiotic supplementation with a low-calorie diet significantly improved quality of life, reduced edema volume, and lowered BMI, though these benefits were primarily attributed to the calorie restriction rather than the synbiotic itself. No significant differences were observed between the synbiotic and placebo groups when both followed a calorie-restricted diet.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese women aged 18-65 with BCRL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefit of perioperative pro-/synbiotics in reducing infections and improving liver function after liver surgery (resection or transplantation).
results_summary: Perioperative pro-/synbiotics significantly reduced infection rates after liver surgery (pooled RR: 0.46), though liver function improvement was inconsistent (1/3 studies in transplantation and 2/5 in resection). Standard protocols for strain selection and administration remain undefined.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing liver resection or transplantation.
effective_dosage: Not specified (combinations and concentrations varied across studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of synbiotics supplementation on lipid and anthropometric profiles in infertile women with PCOS.
results_summary: Synbiotics supplementation significantly decreased LDL and increased HDL levels but did not affect total cholesterol, triglycerides, or anthropometric indices. The clinical significance of these findings remains unclear.
population_specificity: Infertile women with PCOS, aged 19-37 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of synbiotics supplementation in NAFLD patients with normal or low BMI.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results; it describes the study protocol and design.
population_specificity: NAFLD patients with normal or low BMI

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of synbiotic supplementation on clinical and metabolic parameters in patients with rheumatoid arthritis (RA).
results_summary: Synbiotic supplementation significantly reduced inflammation (hs-CRP), improved disease activity (DAS-28), reduced pain (VAS), and enhanced metabolic markers (NO, insulin, HOMA-IR, HOMA-B, GSH) compared to placebo.
population_specificity: Fifty-four patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of synbiotic supplementation on energy and macronutrient homeostasis and muscle wasting in critically ill patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, but the study proposes that gut microbiota modulation through synbiotics may improve clinical prognosis, reduce infectious complications, and enhance energy homeostasis.
population_specificity: Hemodynamically stable, adult, critically ill patients receiving enteral nutrition via a nasogastric tube within 24-48 hours of ICU admission.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether synbiotic supplementation could improve metabolic dysfunction and prevent diabetes in prediabetic adults by modulating intestinal microbiota.
results_summary: The study measured changes in fecal bacteria abundance, metabolic markers (e.g., HbA1C, fasting glucose, insulin resistance), and anthropometric measures (e.g., weight, waist circumference) but did not report specific outcomes in the abstract.
population_specificity: 120 adults with impaired glucose tolerance (prediabetes) in Iran.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of synbiotics on inflammatory markers (hs-CRP, TNF-α, IL-6) in type 2 diabetes patients.
results_summary: Synbiotic supplementation significantly reduced serum concentrations of hs-CRP, IL-6, and TNF-α compared to baseline and placebo, with no significant changes in the placebo group.
population_specificity: 44 type 2 diabetes patients

study_goal: To study the effect of synbiotics in reducing the incidence and severity of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC) among preterm neonates.
results_summary: Synbiotics reduced the incidence of NEC by 50% compared to the non-intervention group (7.4% vs. 14.5%), but did not affect the severity of NEC, sepsis, or mortality.
population_specificity: Preterm neonates (average birth weight 1.4 kg, gestational age 31 weeks) in a tertiary care teaching hospital in south India.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of synbiotics in perioperative nutritional interventions for liver transplant patients, focusing on improving nutritional status and post-transplantation outcomes.
results_summary: The abstract discusses synbiotics as part of perioperative nutritional strategies but does not provide specific results on their effectiveness, suggesting a need for further research to confirm benefits.
population_specificity: Patients with end-stage liver disease undergoing liver transplantation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the anti-inflammatory effects of a synbiotic supplement on inflammation markers in overweight and obese children and adolescents.
results_summary: The synbiotic group showed significant decreases in tumor necrosis-α and interleukin-6 and a significant increase in adiponectin, though these changes were no longer significant after BMI adjustment. No significant change was observed in high-sensitive C-reactive protein.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese children and adolescents aged 6 to 18 years with a BMI ≥ 85th percentile.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether synbiotic supplementation could prevent weight loss in lactating mothers and promote weight gain in their infants.
results_summary: Synbiotic supplementation led to a slight increase in maternal energy intake and prevented weight/BMI loss, while the placebo group showed significant decreases. Infants in the synbiotic group gained significantly more weight than those in the placebo group.
population_specificity: 80 lactating mothers and their infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether synbiotic supplementation reduces the severity of atopic dermatitis (AD) in children aged 1-36 months.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the reduction of AD severity (measured by SCORAD) between the synbiotic and placebo groups, challenging the effectiveness of synbiotics for childhood AD.
population_specificity: Infants aged 1-36 months with moderate to severe atopic dermatitis.
effective_dosage: Daily as a powder (specific amount not stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Tai Chi Softball (TCSB) training on physical health in older men, focusing on muscle strength, flexibility, balance, and blood lipid profiles.
results_summary: After 12 weeks of TCSB training, participants showed significant improvements in muscle strength, flexibility, balance, cardiorespiratory fitness, and blood lipid profiles, including reduced cholesterol and blood pressure levels.
population_specificity: 140 men aged 55-65 years.
effective_dosage: 4-5 sessions per week, 70-90 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the preliminary efficacy and safety of Tai Chi in reducing fatigue and improving cognitive function in patients with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS).
results_summary: The study protocol was approved, and participant recruitment began, but data analysis has not yet been performed, so no results are available.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS).
effective_dosage: 24-style simplified Tai Chi, 3 times per week (2 in-person sessions, 1 self-directed online session).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Tai Chi Chuan (TCC) on mental fatigue and cognitive function in college students, focusing on neural mechanisms related to inhibitory control.
results_summary: The study found that TCC significantly improved mental fatigue and cognitive recovery compared to aerobic exercise and rest, as evidenced by better VAS scores, reaction times, and ERP components like increased NoGo-P3 and Go-P3 amplitudes.
population_specificity: Healthy college students (n=52, with 18 in the TCC group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tai Chi improves cognitive function in elderly patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and explore potential mechanisms, such as changes in serum BDNF levels.
results_summary: The study found that Tai Chi improved cognitive function, executive function, and memory in elderly MCI patients compared to a control group, potentially due to increased serum BDNF expression.
population_specificity: Elderly inpatients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) in a combined medical and elderly care facility in Chengdu.
effective_dosage: Tai Chi exercises performed in addition to daily living activities (specific frequency not detailed).
study_duration: 24 weeks (12 weeks of exercise, 12 weeks of follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Tai Chi in managing aromatase inhibitor arthralgia in breast cancer survivors.
results_summary: The study concluded that Tai Chi likely contributed to improved health outcomes for breast cancer survivors, particularly in managing aromatase inhibitor-related joint pain. Nurses were noted to play a role in guiding patients on the benefits of mind-body practices.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors experiencing aromatase inhibitor arthralgia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical effectiveness and safety of Qigong and Tai Chi (QTC) in improving quality of life (QoL) for cancer patients.
results_summary: QTC improved overall QoL, physiological scores (physical functioning, fatigue, sleep quality), psychological scores (mental health, anxiety), and immunity in cancer patients, though subgroup analyses for depression were not significant. No serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Cancer patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tai Chi Chuan (TCC) improves global cognition, memory, and executive function in older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) and whether these effects vary by intervention duration.
results_summary: Long-term TCC significantly improved global cognition, while short-term TCC did not. Short-term memory improved significantly, but long-term memory did not. Executive function improved significantly regardless of intervention duration.
population_specificity: Adults aged 60 years or older with mild cognitive impairment (MCI), predominantly female (68.95%).
study_duration: Varied (short-term and long-term, exact durations not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tai Chi therapy effectively reduces stress levels in older adults.
results_summary: The study found a significant reduction in stress levels in the experimental group practicing Tai Chi, with mean PSS scores dropping from 27.2 to 10.1, while the control group showed no significant change. Statistical analysis confirmed Tai Chi's effectiveness (t = 10.43, p < 0.05).
population_specificity: Older adults aged 60-80 in selected community areas of Mehsana District.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify barriers and facilitators to the adoption of Tai Chi (alongside qi gong and yoga) for health conditions and evaluate whether these determinants differ by intervention type, health condition, setting, or implementation outcome.
results_summary: The study is a systematic review in progress, so no specific results regarding Tai Chi's effects are reported yet. The abstract outlines the methodology for identifying and analyzing implementation determinants.
population_specificity: Adults with health conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a 9-week Tai Chi Chuan (TCC) training program on executive function, bilateral lower limb muscle activation symmetry, single-leg dynamic balance ability, and brain functional connectivity strength in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that TCC significantly improved single-leg dynamic balance, reduced laterality in lower limb muscle activation, strengthened brain functional connectivity, and enhanced executive function with reduced reaction times and increased prefrontal cortex oxygenation. TCC showed superior intervention effects compared to brisk walking in improving neuromuscular function.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Tai Chi and Qigong (TCQ) on physical function and psychiatric symptoms in adults with schizophrenia or mood disorders.
results_summary: TCQ significantly improved physical function and psychiatric symptoms in individuals with serious mental illness, particularly mood disorders, but showed no significant effect on physical function in those with schizophrenia. The effects on physical function were found to covary with improvements in psychiatric symptoms.
population_specificity: Adults with schizophrenia or mood disorders (n = 1243, mean age 53 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of traditional Chinese exercises (TCEs), including Tai Chi, on anxiety and depression in older adults and identify optimal exercise parameters for these outcomes.
results_summary: TCEs significantly improved anxiety and depression in older adults, with the largest effects observed at specific durations (12–16 weeks for anxiety, 24 weeks for depression), frequencies (3–4 times/week for anxiety, 5–7 times/week for depression), and session lengths (40–60 minutes). However, significant heterogeneity was noted across studies.
population_specificity: Older adults
effective_dosage: 3–7 times per week, 40–60 minutes per session

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Tai Chi with multisensory stimulation could improve cognitive function, sensory function, and brain activation in older adults with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study is ongoing, so results are not yet available. The abstract outlines the methodology but does not report findings on Tai Chi's effects.
population_specificity: Adults aged 60+ with mild cognitive impairment (MCI) in Suzhou and Shanghai, China.
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involves Tai Chi practice, but frequency/duration details are not provided).
study_duration: 6 months (with follow-up assessments at 3, 6, and 9 months).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effectiveness and safety of Tai Chi in managing cardiometabolic risk factors (CRFs) such as obesity, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, and glycemic dysregulation.
results_summary: Tai Chi significantly improved lipid profiles, blood pressure, blood glucose, and body composition compared to nonexercise interventions and showed modest benefits over other exercises. No serious adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Adults with cardiometabolic risk factors (e.g., obesity, hyperlipidemia, hypertension, glycemic dysregulation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Tai Chi, dance, and a control group on physical functions and mental benefits in non-clinical adults.
results_summary: The study predicted improvements in mental wellbeing during the learning phase and physical parameters during the practicing phase, though specific results for Tai Chi were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Non-clinical adults aged 18-60

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare dynamic stability and limb support force production during Tai Chi gait, with and without ground support perturbations, in older and younger adults.
results_summary: Tai Chi gait decreased margin of stability and increased vertical force impulse compared to comfortable walking. Medial ground support perturbation further challenged dynamic stability, while older adults showed increased margin of stability compared to younger adults.
population_specificity: Ten older adults and ten younger adults.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tai Chi improves physical fitness and alpha-band power in college students.
results_summary: The Tai Chi group showed greater improvement in long jump performance compared to the control group (13.73 ± 15.54 cm vs. 4.91 ± 9.24 cm) and an increase in alpha-band power, while the control group experienced a decrease.
population_specificity: College students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of Tai Chi on balance, mobility, and gait functions in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: Tai Chi significantly improved balance, mobility, and gait speed compared to conventional medication and other exercise therapies, but showed no significant improvement in gait endurance or amplitude.
population_specificity: Patients with Parkinson's disease (963 cases from four countries).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of four optimal Tai Chi forms (OTC) on reducing knee osteoarthritis (KOA) pain in Hispanic individuals.
results_summary: The 2-week OTC training significantly reduced knee pain with a large effect size (4.14 ± 1.21 vs. 1.29 ± 1.70 cm, p < 0.027) and was about 20% more effective than an existing 12-week Tai Chi program.
population_specificity: Seven Hispanic adults with mild to moderate KOA.
effective_dosage: Four Tai Chi forms, frequency not specified.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Tai Chi interventions in promoting self-esteem among adults through a systematic review and meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that Tai Chi significantly improved self-esteem in adults, with a standardized mean difference of 0.46 (95% CI: 0.18-0.74; p = 0.001). However, most included studies had high risk of bias or methodological concerns.
population_specificity: Adults, with specific mention of older adults and patients with chronic illnesses.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute Tai Chi practice enhances emotional memory and prefrontal cortex activation compared to cycling and a resting control condition.
results_summary: Tai Chi significantly improved positive emotional memory accuracy and increased left dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (L-DLPFC) activation compared to cycling and rest, with a strong correlation between L-DLPFC activation and memory accuracy. Cycling showed modest improvements, while the control group had no significant changes.
population_specificity: 36 healthy university students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of different Tai Chi styles on motor function in older adults with functional impairments.
results_summary: The study found strong evidence supporting the effectiveness of Yang-style Tai Chi in improving motor function, particularly in balance, gait, mobility, strength, and fall rates. Five assessment methods were identified as suitable for evaluating these outcomes.
population_specificity: Older adults with functional impairments, including mild cognitive impairment, nonspecific low back pain, preclinical disabilities, chronic diseases, poor balance, osteoarthritis, Parkinson's disease, sarcopenia, and those at risk of falls.
effective_dosage: Yang-style 24-movement Tai Chi, practiced two to five times a week for 60 minutes per session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tai Chi, alone or combined with music therapy, improves cognitive function in older adults with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI).
results_summary: Tai Chi combined with music therapy significantly improved cognitive function (MoCA, MMSE, attention, visuospatial skills, and delayed recall) in older adults with MCI, outperforming Tai Chi alone. The control group showed declines in language repetition and delayed recall.
population_specificity: Older adults (66 participants) diagnosed with Mild Cognitive Impairment (MCI).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention involved Tai Chi sessions, frequency not detailed).
study_duration: 12 weeks (though results mention 16-week improvements, possibly a typo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Tai Chi, enhanced by communication technologies, in improving cognitive and physical functioning in patients with mild cognitive impairment, and to compare these effects with traditional Tai Chi.
results_summary: The meta-analysis revealed significant improvements in cognitive (Mini-Mental State Examination scores) and physical (Timed Up and Go results) functioning in patients with mild cognitive impairment following Tai Chi intervention. Communication technology-based Tai Chi showed greater benefits in promoting rehabilitation compared to traditional Tai Chi.
population_specificity: Patients with mild cognitive impairment (1,877 participants across 16 studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 1-Hz rTMS could enhance the benefits of Tai Chi in improving sleep quality and cognitive function in older adults with sleep disorders and mild cognitive impairment.
results_summary: The study found that combining Tai Chi with 1-Hz rTMS significantly improved sleep quality (lower PSQI scores) and cognitive function (higher MoCA scores) compared to Tai Chi alone, with sustained benefits at the 12-week follow-up. Adverse events were minimal and not significantly different between groups.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 60-75 years with sleep disorders and mild cognitive impairment.
effective_dosage: 30 sessions of 60-minute Tai Chi (24-form simplified) 5 times per week for 6 weeks, alongside 30 sessions of 1-Hz rTMS or sham rTMS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a novel body weight support-Tai Chi Yunshou (BWS-TCY) training method for improving upper limb dysfunction in stroke patients.
results_summary: The BWS-TCY intervention significantly improved upper limb motor function (FMA-UE, WMFT) and proprioception (AAE) compared to conventional rehabilitation, with some measures showing better performance than robot-assisted training. Daily living activities (MBI) also improved, though quality of life (SS-QOL) showed no significant difference between groups.
population_specificity: Stroke patients with upper limb dysfunction (n=93).
effective_dosage: 30 minutes of BWS-TCY daily, combined with 30 minutes of conventional rehabilitation, 5 days per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of Tai Chi Chuan on physical function, hematological metabolic biomarkers, sleep quality, and mental health in breast cancer patients.
results_summary: The study found that Tai Chi improved motor function, sleep quality, and certain hematological biomarkers (e.g., albumin, HDL-CH) while maintaining stable weight, blood pressure, and mental health metrics. Waist-hip ratio decreased, and some arm girth measurements showed a shrinking trend.
population_specificity: 37 breast cancer patients who had completed surgery treatment.
effective_dosage: Not specified (12-week intervention, frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore adherence to a Tai Chi exercise program among People Living with Dementia (PLWD) and its effects on their Quality of Life (QoL), including factors influencing adherence.
results_summary: The study found high adherence (69.19% class attendance) among PLWD, with higher QoL in highly adherent participants. Health conditions of PLWD and their carers were significant barriers to adherence, while baseline moderate physical activity was a positive predictor.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling People Living with Dementia (PLWD) and their carers.
effective_dosage: Not specified (Tai Chi exercise intervention in addition to usual care).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the therapeutic efficacy of Tai Chi versus conventional exercise on physical performance, sleep efficiency, and quality of life in older adults with cognitive impairment.
results_summary: Tai Chi significantly improved physical performance, sleep efficiency, and quality of life in older adults with mild to moderate cognitive impairment, outperforming conventional exercise in physical performance improvements.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 81.0 ± 7.4 years) with mild to moderate cognitive impairment living in a nursing home.
effective_dosage: 12 weeks of Tai Chi intervention (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of Tai Chi on emotional well-being and quality of life in elderly individuals with depression.
results_summary: Tai Chi significantly improved depressive symptoms as measured by the Geriatric Depression Scale but did not show a significant advantage on the Hamilton Depression Scale. Subgroup analysis favored a six-month duration for greater benefits.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals aged ≥60 diagnosed with depression.
effective_dosage: Not specified (movements, frequency, and duration details were noted as needing further research).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the feasibility and relative efficacy of Tai Chi compared to a Wellness intervention in addressing symptoms of Gulf War Illness (GWI), including chronic pain, fatigue, mood changes, and cognitive functioning.
results_summary: Tai Chi was found to be feasible and acceptable, with no adverse events reported. It showed greater reductions in depressed mood and more rapid initial improvements in verbal learning compared to the Wellness intervention, though both groups had similar effects on pain interference.
population_specificity: Male and female veterans with Gulf War Illness (GWI).
study_duration: 12 weeks, with follow-ups at 3 and 9 months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefits of Tai Chi and Yoga on psychological wellbeing and perceived mental and physical health in female university employees.
results_summary: The study found significant reductions in ruminative thoughts, somatic anxiety, and state anxiety, along with improved perceived mental health after 10 Tai Chi/Yoga sessions. Immediate reductions in state anxiety were also observed after single sessions.
population_specificity: Female university employees and faculty members.
study_duration: Duration of intervention not explicitly stated (implied by 10 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether long-term Tai Chi practitioners exhibit better online control of goal-directed behavior during precision fitting tasks compared to sedentary and brisk walking groups.
results_summary: The Tai Chi group showed significantly faster completion times, higher hand and trunk velocities, and better center of pressure control during precision tasks compared to sedentary and brisk walking groups, suggesting improved motor control.
population_specificity: 36 older adults divided into sedentary, brisk walking, and Tai Chi groups based on exercise habits.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of Tai Chi on improving cognitive function in patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: Tai Chi significantly improved cognitive function in MCI patients, as measured by the Montreal Cognitive Assessment, Delayed Recall Test, verbal fluency test, and Trail Making Test. Subgroup analyses indicated that different forms of Tai Chi (e.g., 24-forms, 10-forms) had varying levels of effectiveness on specific cognitive domains.
population_specificity: Patients with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tai Chi effectively reverses the prefrail state in older adults and improves biomarkers of immunosenescence, while also exploring the optimal timing for the exercise regimen.
results_summary: The study found that Tai Chi improved physical performance, frailty index scores, muscle strength, and mass, along with secondary outcomes like quality of life, balance, and immune risk profile. The timing of Tai Chi practice (morning vs. afternoon) was also investigated to maximize therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: Prefrail older adults aged 60-75 years.
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency and intensity not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal dosage of Tai Chi exercise for improving sleep quality in older adults through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Tai Chi significantly improved sleep quality in older adults, particularly when practiced for at least 150 minutes per week. Sessions lasting 60 minutes or 25-45 minutes, and programs lasting 8-12 or 16-24 weeks, also showed significant benefits.
population_specificity: Older adults (1,166 participants across nine studies).
effective_dosage: 150-300 minutes per week, with single sessions of 25-45 minutes or 60 minutes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effectiveness of a 12-week progressive exercise and Tai Chi snacking program on physical function and psychological outcomes in pre-frail older adults.
results_summary: The program significantly improved lower extremity strength, balance, and mobility, with consistent benefits observed at 4, 8, and 12 weeks. Participants also reported the program as accessible, beneficial, and confidence-boosting for physical activity.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling pre-frail older adults with impaired strength and balance (n=90).
effective_dosage: Not specified (progressive exercise and Tai Chi snacking program).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically evaluate Tai Chi's effects on balance, fall prevention, and physical function in older adults.
results_summary: Tai Chi significantly improved balance and physical function, particularly in the Berg Balance Scale (BBS), one-leg standing with eyes closed (OLS-C), and Timed up-and-go test (TUG), while also reducing fear of falling (FOF). Some tests like the Tinetti Balance Test (TBT) and Short Physical Performance Battery (SPPB) showed no statistically significant effects.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of a 7-posture Wheelchair/Adaptive Tai Chi Chuan (W/A TCC) training program on healthcare providers within the VA healthcare system.
results_summary: The study found increased confidence levels among healthcare providers following the training, with no significant differences between Recreational Therapists and other providers. Participants reported meaningful impacts, supporting W/A TCC as a strategy to enhance holistic veteran healthcare.
population_specificity: VA healthcare providers, including Recreational Therapists.
study_duration: Training program facilitated since 2016 (duration not explicitly stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of an online unsupervised Tai Chi program, compared to online education alone, on knee pain and physical function in people with knee osteoarthritis.
results_summary: The study is a randomized controlled trial in progress, so results are not yet available. It will compare changes in knee pain and physical function between the Tai Chi intervention group and the education control group at 12 weeks.
population_specificity: 178 people with a clinical diagnosis of knee osteoarthritis.
effective_dosage: 12-week unsupervised online Tai Chi program, 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Tai Chi and Baduanjin on cognitive function, shoulder joint function, anxiety, depression, fatigue, sleep quality, and quality of life in breast cancer patients compared to traditional treatment methods.
results_summary: Tai Chi and Baduanjin significantly improved cognitive function, shoulder joint function, sleep quality, and quality of life while reducing anxiety, depression, and fatigue symptoms in breast cancer patients, with results comparable to or better than traditional treatments.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients (1,247 participants across 16 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the characteristics of randomized controlled trials (RCTs) examining mind-body interventions, including Tai Chi, for managing ME/CFS symptoms and identify areas for future optimization.
results_summary: The study found no RCTs on Tai Chi for ME/CFS, only Qigong trials. Qigong showed emerging evidence for benefits on physical and emotional health outcomes in ME/CFS patients.
population_specificity: Patients with myalgic encephalomyelitis/chronic fatigue syndrome (ME/CFS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the feasibility, acceptability, adherence, and participant burden of Tai Chi and a Wellness comparison intervention for Veterans with PTSD and chronic pain.
results_summary: The study adapted and piloted remote Tai Chi and Wellness interventions but did not report efficacy results, focusing instead on feasibility and acceptability for future large-scale trials.
population_specificity: Veterans diagnosed with PTSD and chronic pain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the efficacy of Tai Chi, alone and combined with rTMS, in improving sleep disturbance in older adults, while also examining the influence of baseline depressive symptoms.
results_summary: Tai Chi combined with active rTMS significantly reduced sleep onset latency compared to sham rTMS, with greater benefits in sleep efficiency and wake time after sleep onset for those without depressive symptoms. Those with depressive symptoms showed improvements across Tai Chi groups (with or without rTMS) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Older adults (mean age 67.68 years, 73.68% female) with sleep disturbance.

study_goal: The researchers sought to evaluate whether a virtually delivered mind-body program integrating tai chi, qigong, and meditation (VDTQM) is effective for treating low back pain (LBP).
results_summary: The treatment group showed statistically and clinically significant improvements in pain-related disability, pain intensity, sleep quality, and quality of life compared to the control group, with benefits persisting one month post-treatment. No adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: Adults (≥18 years) with chronic low back pain (≥6 weeks), excluding pregnant individuals, those with prior tai chi experience, or recent spine surgery.
effective_dosage: 60-minute live online group classes, twice weekly for 12 weeks.
study_duration: 12 weeks (with follow-up assessments up to 16 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of Tai Chi on BMI, exercise capacity, and mental health in overweight/obese adults, as well as factors influencing adherence to Tai Chi.
results_summary: The study found that Tai Chi significantly reduced BMI, improved exercise capacity, and enhanced mental health (measured by GWB, PSQI, and CSES) in the experimental group. Adherence was higher in the experimental group (87.5%) compared to the control group (57.9%).
population_specificity: Overweight/obese adults (20 participants, 10 per group).
effective_dosage: Not specified (8-week intervention with standard vs. simplified Tai Chi).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of Tai Chi, along with qigong and yoga, on fatigue and associated symptoms in adults with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) or post-COVID syndrome (PCS).
results_summary: Tai Chi, along with other mindful exercises, was found to be more effective than control interventions in reducing fatigue and improving anxiety, depression, and sleep quality, though the certainty of evidence was low or very low due to methodological concerns.
population_specificity: Adults with chronic fatigue syndrome (CFS) or post-COVID syndrome (PCS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of AI-based exercise feedback versus standard training on physical and mental health outcomes in older adults practicing Tai Chi.
results_summary: All groups improved in movement accuracy, grip strength, quality of life, and depression, but only the AI feedback group showed significant balance improvements. The AI feedback group outperformed others in movement accuracy and balance.
population_specificity: Older adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the feasibility and potential benefits of a 12-week Tai Chi and Yoga (TY combining) program on cardiorespiratory and lung functions, functional fitness, and quality of life in older males with COPD.
results_summary: The TY combining program significantly improved pulmonary functions, functional fitness, quality of life, and fatigue over 12 weeks, with functional fitness improvements observed as early as four weeks. The intervention was safe and feasible, with no reported complications.
population_specificity: Older males (age 70 ± 6 years) diagnosed with moderate to severe COPD.
effective_dosage: Not specified (12-week program, frequency not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether integrating Tai Chi's early movement features with neurodevelopmental therapy, objectively assessed via biomechanical analysis, could improve motor function and rehabilitation outcomes in stroke survivors.
results_summary: The study proposes that biomechanics-based Tai Chi training improves muscle strength and mobility more effectively than traditional walking training, with outcomes assessed through kinematic/dynamic data, electromyography, and standardized clinical scales. Results will be evaluated post-intervention, but preliminary findings suggest potential benefits.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors with motor dysfunction and lower extremity muscle weakness.
effective_dosage: 24-form Tai Chi practiced three times weekly.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an 8-week Tai Chi program based on positive youth development (PYD) could improve career adaptability and psychological needs satisfaction in college students.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in career adaptability and satisfaction of basic psychological needs in the intervention group compared to the control group, with mediation analysis showing that psychological needs satisfaction mediated the increase in career adaptability.
population_specificity: 70 senior college students
effective_dosage: Organized 8-week Tai Chi program (frequency not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an unsupervised online Tai Chi program for people with hip/knee osteoarthritis using the AHEAD framework.
results_summary: The study identified and refined 10 Tai Chi movements (Yang Style 10 form) for inclusion in the program, which was rated as appropriate and safe by 92% of panel members. The final program, "My Joint Tai Chi," is being evaluated in a randomized controlled trial.
population_specificity: People with hip/knee osteoarthritis aged 45+ years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify changes in prefrontal and motor area activation during Tai Chi in patients with Type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM) and major depressive disorder (MDD) using fNIRS.
results_summary: Patients with T2DM and MDD showed decreased activation and abnormal lateralization in prefrontal and motor areas, as well as reduced functional connectivity. The oxyhemoglobin concentration in the dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) was negatively correlated with depression scores.
population_specificity: Elderly adults (≥60 years) with T2DM and MDD, T2DM alone, or healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Tai Chi and aerobic exercise on antioxidant markers and cognitive performance in Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: Tai Chi significantly increased glutathione (GSH) levels but did not significantly affect other antioxidant markers or cognitive performance. The control group showed decreased SOD activity and MMSE scores, while Tai Chi helped preserve cognitive function compared to controls.
population_specificity: 61 individuals with Parkinson's disease (21 in the Tai Chi group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Mindfulness-enhanced Tai Chi Chuan (MTCC) versus traditional Tai Chi Chuan (TCC) on mental and physical health in beginners.
results_summary: The MTCC group showed significantly greater improvements in mindfulness, anxiety, stress, and physical fitness compared to the TCC group, but no significant differences in depression.
population_specificity: 119 healthy college students new to Tai Chi Chuan training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine trends and hotspots in Tai Chi treatment for osteoporosis using bibliometric analysis to guide future research.
results_summary: The study found that Tai Chi research for osteoporosis is growing, with China and the US leading in publications. Current research focuses on mechanisms like beneficial factor secretion, exercise load, and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Individuals with osteoporosis (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand how music has been used in Tai Chi practice and whether it could optimize Tai Chi's benefits.
results_summary: Practicing Tai Chi with music may enhance positive perceptions (e.g., motivation, enjoyment) and instructional quality, especially for beginners, but effects on health outcomes remain inconclusive due to study heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Tai Chi practitioners, particularly beginners.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether Tai Chi practice mitigates age-related declines in neural network connectivity by comparing temporal and spatial features in younger adults, older adults, and older Tai Chi practitioners.
results_summary: Aging was associated with decreased functional connectivity within and between brain networks, while Tai Chi practice appeared to counteract these declines, improving connectivity in older practitioners compared to non-practitioners. The findings suggest Tai Chi may enhance neural network efficiency and stability, supporting its role in healthy brain aging.
population_specificity: Healthy younger adult controls (YACs, n=15), healthy older adult controls (OACs, n=15), and older Tai Chi practitioners (TCOAs, n=15).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of Tai Chi (BaFa WuBu) on vascular endothelial function, atherosclerosis progression, and lipid metabolism in postmenopausal women using real-time heart rate monitoring.
results_summary: The study found that 24 weeks of Tai Chi significantly improved vascular health, reduced systolic blood pressure, vascular obstruction, and lipid levels, while enhancing vascular endothelial function. Diastolic blood pressure and FMD (flow-mediated dilation) also showed significant improvements.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal middle-aged and elderly women.
effective_dosage: 24-week Tai Chi (BaFa WuBu) training intervention with real-time heart rate monitoring (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tai Chi improves memory performance in older adults by enhancing subjective and objective sleep quality.
results_summary: Tai Chi improved subjective sleep (ISI and PSQI daytime dysfunction), objective sleep (actigraphy-assessed sleep onset latency), and memory performance (digit span forward and visual spatial memory tasks). Sleep improvements mediated the link between Tai Chi and memory enhancement.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 56-79 years (mean age 67.36).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of different intensities of Tan Tui exercises on posture control in college students enrolled in a Tai Chi Elective Course.
results_summary: The study protocol proposes to assess posture control improvements using various tests (UST, SEBT, RPT, KJPP) after 6 weeks of Tan Tui interventions at low, medium, and high intensities compared to regular Tai Chi training. Results are pending as this is a study protocol.
population_specificity: College students in a Tai Chi Elective Course in China (n=76).
effective_dosage: Low, medium, and high-intensity Tan Tui exercises (2 times/week, 20 min/session).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effect of Tai Chi exercise on bone health and fall prevention in postmenopausal women through a meta-analysis.
results_summary: Tai Chi significantly improved vertebral bone density and health status scores in postmenopausal women but showed no significant effects on serum calcium, clinical balance, number of falls, or total falls.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (1,272 participants, 628 in Tai Chi group, 644 in control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prolonged Tai Chi therapy improves cognitive capabilities and modulates immune-inflammatory pathways in individuals with schizophrenia.
results_summary: Tai Chi therapy reduced TNF-α and IL-5 levels and improved clinical symptom scores (SAPS, SANS, PSS, SOFS, RBANS) compared to routine treatment, suggesting benefits via immunomodulatory pathways.
population_specificity: 90 clinically diagnosed schizophrenia patients (62 analyzed post-intervention).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the biomechanical differences between Tai Chi elastic band exercises and elastic band resistance training to support Tai Chi's application in health interventions.
results_summary: The Tai Chi group showed smaller shoulder joint angles and slower movement speeds but greater elbow flexion angles and muscle stimulation in specific muscles compared to the resistance training group. The study concluded that joint angles, angular velocity, and hand position differences influenced torque and muscle activity between the two exercises.
population_specificity: 26 male participants, divided into two groups of 13 each.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the feasibility and clinical outcomes of combining multimodal chiropractic care (MCC) and Tai Chi (TC) for managing chronic nonspecific neck pain (CNNP) in nurses.
results_summary: The study found modest improvements in neck pain and disability-related outcomes after 16 weeks of combined MCC and TC interventions. Qualitative feedback highlighted TC's role in relaxation, increased body awareness, and improved posture, though scheduling difficulties were a barrier.
population_specificity: Nurses with self-reported chronic nonspecific neck pain.
effective_dosage: Not specified (adherence rate for TC classes was 62.5%).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Tai Chi versus aerobic exercise in improving drug cravings, attention bias, and physical fitness in men with methamphetamine use disorder (MUD).
results_summary: The study found that a 12-week Tai Chi intervention significantly improved attention bias and reaction time compared to running, but no significant improvements were observed in drug cravings or other physical fitness variables.
population_specificity: Men with methamphetamine use disorder (mean age 39.1 ± 8.7 years).
effective_dosage: 60 minutes of moderate-intensity Tai Chi (65-75% HRmax) three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tai Chi training improves functionality, dynamic balance, kinesiophobia, and quality of life in athletes with Functional Ankle Instability (FAI).
results_summary: The Tai Chi group showed significant improvements in ankle instability (CAIT score), dynamic balance (SEBT reach distance), reduced kinesiophobia (TSK), and enhanced physical quality of life (SF-12 physical component), with no effect on mental quality of life (SF-12 mental component).
population_specificity: Athletes with Functional Ankle Instability (FAI)
effective_dosage: Tailored exercise protocol with three-phase progression (specific dosage not detailed)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining Tai Chi (TC) with repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) could produce synergistic and longer-lasting benefits for sleep disturbances in older adults compared to TC alone or usual treatment.
results_summary: The study found that TC combined with rTMS significantly improved insomnia severity at both post-intervention and 3-month follow-up, while TC alone showed significant improvement only at follow-up. The combination also improved sleep efficiency, total sleep time, mood states, and mental quality of life, though the underlying mechanisms remained unclear.
population_specificity: Older community-dwelling adults with sleep disturbances.
effective_dosage: TC was conducted three times per week for 4 weeks.
study_duration: 4 weeks of intervention, with assessments up to 3 months post-intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of Tai Chi-based rehabilitation exercises on physical and psychological health outcomes for patients with coronary heart disease (CHD).
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that Tai Chi significantly improved physical function (e.g., 6MWT, VO2 max, NYHA class) and psychological health (e.g., anxiety, depression, mental health components) in CHD patients compared to conventional therapy. The evidence levels ranged from very low to moderate.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary heart disease (CHD).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness and satisfaction of a virtual Tai Chi program for older Veterans at risk of loneliness or physical deconditioning.
results_summary: Completers showed statistically significant improvements in physical function (30CST) and loneliness (DJGS), with high satisfaction and adherence rates (84% attendance). The program was deemed effective and satisfying for the target population.
population_specificity: Older Veterans at risk of loneliness and/or physical deconditioning.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of traditional Tai Chi and augmented reality Tai Chi on depression in elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that the VR-augmented Tai Chi group showed a more significant reduction in depression compared to the traditional Tai Chi and control groups, with statistical significance (p ≤ 0.05).
population_specificity: Elderly individuals aged over 60 from the Beijing Medical Center.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of chen tai chi and aerobic exercises on cognition, balance, cardiopulmonary fitness, and quality of life in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that tai chi improved cognition and static balance, but aerobic exercise showed more significant improvements in cognition, balance, cardiopulmonary fitness, and quality of life. No statistically significant differences were found between groups for dynamic balance, cardiopulmonary fitness, and quality of life.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 60-75 years
effective_dosage: Exercise sessions held four days per week

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of Body Weight Support-Tai Chi Yunshou (BWS-TCY) on upper limb motor function in stroke survivors based on neurobiomechanics.
results_summary: The study will compare BWS-TCY with other rehabilitation methods (Robot-assisted training and Conventional rehabilitation training) to assess its effectiveness in improving upper limb function in stroke survivors, with results pending publication.
population_specificity: Stroke survivors (36 participants) and healthy elderly individuals (22 participants).
effective_dosage: 20 minutes of BWS-TCY training daily, combined with 20 minutes of Conventional rehabilitation training (CRT), 5 days a week.
study_duration: 12 weeks of intervention, with a 12-week follow-up period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tai Chi training improves depression symptoms in perimenopausal women and explore its mechanism by examining serum kynurenine metabolites.
results_summary: Tai Chi training significantly reduced depression symptoms, increased serum kynurenic acid (KYNA), and decreased kynurenine (KYN), quinolinic acid (QUIN), and the KYN/Trp ratio, suggesting regulation of abnormal kynurenine metabolism as a potential mechanism.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal women with depression (72 participants) and healthy perimenopausal women (36 participants).
effective_dosage: 24 simplified Tai Chi exercises (specific frequency not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to recognize Tai Chi movements using IMUs and TCNs and evaluate the effectiveness of precision interventions for elderly males.
results_summary: The TCN model accurately identified Tai Chi movements (82.6%-94.4% accuracy). Both intervention groups improved in grip strength, quality of life, and depression, but only the precision group showed significant balance improvements.
