population_specificity: 60 elderly males (intervention study) and 70 skilled Tai Chi practitioners (movement recognition).
effective_dosage: Weekly real-time IMU feedback for the precision intervention group (specific Tai Chi dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Tai Chi Chuan and aerobic exercise on motor symptoms and neurocognitive performance in early-stage Parkinson's disease patients.
results_summary: Tai Chi Chuan improved motor symptoms (lower UPDRS-III scores) and enhanced neurocognitive performance (increased ERP P3 amplitude) but did not improve accuracy rates or ERP N2 performance. Aerobic exercise showed broader cognitive benefits (faster reaction times and larger P3 amplitudes) but Tai Chi was still effective for specific outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with idiopathic Parkinson's disease (early-stage).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Tai Chi on disease and symptom management in COPD patients.
results_summary: Tai Chi positively impacted lung function, exercise capacity, social support, muscle strength, self-care, and mental health symptoms like anxiety and depression. It was found to be superior to routine care and mind-body breathing and comparable to pulmonary rehabilitation.
population_specificity: COPD patients, including those with comorbidities.
effective_dosage: Not specified (styles mentioned: Qigong, Sun, and Yang).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Tai Chi on chronic low back pain through meta-analysis and investigate influencing factors such as intervention type, Tai Chi school, and session frequency.
results_summary: Tai Chi significantly reduced pain intensity and disability in chronic low back pain patients, with large effect sizes and statistical significance. It also improved physical and mental health quality of life, with low adverse reaction incidence. No significant differences were found between Tai Chi styles or session frequencies.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic low back pain (886 cases across 10 RCTs).
study_duration: Varied by study (not specified in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of a hybrid online and offline Tai Chi rehabilitation program on oxidative stress and inflammatory responses in patients with coronary heart disease.
results_summary: The Tai Chi program significantly reduced oxidative stress markers (MDA) and improved antioxidative (SOD) and anti-inflammatory (IL-10) responses, while the conventional exercise group only showed improvement in SOD. A positive correlation was found between SOD and IL-10, and between MDA and TNF-α.
population_specificity: Patients with coronary heart disease (ages 62.07 ± 9.076 in the Tai Chi group, 61.90 ± 9.700 in the control group).
effective_dosage: 1-hour sessions, 3 times per week for 12 weeks (total 36 sessions).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Tai Chi in attenuating mild cognitive impairment (MCI) among the elderly population.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that Tai Chi was as effective as conventional exercise in improving Montreal Cognitive Assessment scores but more effective than the control group in improving Mini-Mental Status Examination scores, suggesting it can improve cognitive function and slow cognitive impairment in elderly patients.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with or at risk of mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tai Chi Rouli Ball could improve bone health, including bone density and metabolism markers, in perimenopausal women.
results_summary: The Tai Chi Rouli Ball group showed significant increases in spine bone density, bone mineral content, and improved bone metabolism markers (e.g., higher estrogen, lower FSH and LH) compared to the control group. Calcium levels also increased significantly, while other markers like ALP, P, and Mg showed non-significant changes.
population_specificity: Perimenopausal women aged 45-55 years from community senior centers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Tai Chi on cognitive function in older adults with amnestic mild cognitive impairment (aMCI), focusing on peripheral exosome processes and their potential role in mediating these effects.
results_summary: Tai Chi improved global cognitive function and memory, increased right hippocampus volume, and enhanced functional connectivity between the hippocampus and cuneus. The study also identified up-regulated exosomal protein LRP1, which was associated with improved memory and hippocampal plasticity.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults with amnestic mild cognitive impairment (aMCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Tai Chi versus aerobic exercise in alleviating dyspnea in patients with advanced lung cancer.
results_summary: Tai Chi significantly improved overall dyspnea at 16 weeks and one year, and both Tai Chi and aerobic exercise alleviated lung cancer-specific dyspnea at one year, with Tai Chi showing a greater effect.
population_specificity: Patients with advanced lung cancer (n=226).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tai Chi could reduce inflammation markers in breast cancer survivors with insomnia, compared to cognitive behavioral therapy for insomnia (CBT-I).
results_summary: Tai Chi resulted in greater decreases in plasma IL-6 and TLR-4 stimulated monocyte production of IL-6 and TNF compared to CBT-I, indicating stronger anti-inflammatory effects. Both interventions reduced inflammatory gene transcripts and increased anti-viral gene transcripts, but Tai Chi showed more durable decreases in systemic and cellular inflammation.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors with insomnia (n=90, randomized to Tai Chi or CBT-I).
effective_dosage: Not specified (frequency/duration implied by intervention length).
study_duration: 3 months of intervention, followed by 12 months of post-intervention monitoring (15 months total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of Tai Chi, resistance training, and their combination on oxidative stress, blood glucose, lipid metabolism, and quality of life in elderly patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus.
results_summary: Tai Chi reduced oxidative stress, improved blood glucose and lipid control, and enhanced quality of life in elderly T2DM patients. The combination intervention further reduced oxidative stress but did not show additional benefits for blood glucose, lipids, or quality of life compared to single interventions.
population_specificity: Elderly patients with type 2 diabetes mellitus (n=24 in Tai Chi group).
effective_dosage: 40 minutes per session, 3 times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Tai Chi versus aerobic exercise on perceived cognitive function in metastatic lung cancer survivors with cognitive impairment and examine the mediating role of psychoneurological symptoms.
results_summary: Tai Chi significantly improved perceived cognitive function compared to aerobic exercise and control groups at 16 weeks and 1 year, with reductions in sleep disturbance, fatigue, anxiety, and depression mediating these effects. Anxiety played a particularly significant role in early improvements.
population_specificity: Metastatic lung cancer survivors with perceived cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combined intervention of resistance band use and Tai Chi could improve physical fitness, frailty conditions, and quality of life in prefrail older adults.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in frailty index, self-care abilities, physical fitness (back and arm curl), physical activity, quality of life (physiological), and heart rate variability, but no improvements in balance or lower limb flexibility.
population_specificity: Prefrail older adult males (n=34).
effective_dosage: Tai Chi three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Tai Chi and conventional exercise in reducing depressive symptoms in older adults with chronic insomnia and depressive symptoms.
results_summary: The study found that Tai Chi was effective in improving depressive symptoms, subjective sleep quality, and other secondary outcomes, though comparative efficacy with conventional exercise was not yet determined.
population_specificity: Older adults aged ≥60 years with chronic insomnia and depressive symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of long-term Tai Chi practice on standing balance control in older adults using traditional and non-traditional methods.
results_summary: Tai Chi practitioners showed improved sensory reweighting (greater reliance on proprioception and less on the vestibular system) and increased complexity of standing balance control. They exhibited greater sway velocity and path length, linked with higher complexity, but no significant relationship was found in the control group.
population_specificity: Older adults (36 Tai Chi practitioners and 36 non-practitioners).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to estimate the mean effect of Tai Chi/Qigong (TCQ) on depression and anxiety in adults with cancer and examine moderating factors influencing these effects.
results_summary: TCQ showed small-to-moderate efficacy in reducing depression and anxiety symptoms in cancer patients, with greater antidepressant effects observed when improvements in function-related outcomes were also achieved. The effect size was 0.29 for anxiety and 0.35 for depression, though depression results exhibited heterogeneity.
population_specificity: Adults with cancer (patients and survivors)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different types of Tai Chi exercises on preventing falls in older adults to identify the most effective intervention.
results_summary: The study found that 24-form simplified Tai Chi was more effective than other types (Yang style, Sun style, and TCEP) in reducing fall incidence and improving balance (measured by BBS). Network meta-analysis ranked 24-form as the most effective, followed by Yang style and Sun style.
population_specificity: Older adults (3,470 participants across 17 trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an 8-week Tai Chi exercise intervention could improve sleep quality in older adults.
results_summary: The study found that Tai Chi significantly improved subjective sleep quality (PSQI and IEI scores), increased time spent in bed, total sleep time, and non-REM sleep stage 2. Tai Chi also appeared to reduce general drowsiness and optimize sleep structure.
population_specificity: Older adults aged 60 years and above from the community around Southwest University in Chongqing City.
effective_dosage: 60-minute Tai Chi sessions, three times per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of 24-form simplified Tai Chi training on college students' executive functions and frontal brain electrical activity during the COVID-19 pandemic.
results_summary: Tai Chi training improved executive inhibitory control (increased accuracy and decreased reaction time) and enhanced localized brain activity (increased θ band power in frontal areas), while the control group showed decreased α band power.
population_specificity: College students during the COVID-19 pandemic.
effective_dosage: 36 sessions (3 sessions per week, 45 min each).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of Tai Chi lower extremity exercise (TC LEE), 8-form Tai Chi (8-form TC), and a stretching control intervention for improving balance and functional mobility in older adults.
results_summary: Both TC LEE and 8-form TC significantly improved balance and functional mobility compared to stretching, with TC LEE showing greater improvement in functional mobility as measured by the TUG test. The improvements were statistically significant across multiple balance and mobility metrics.
population_specificity: Older adults (average age 79 ± 6 years) from assisted living facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the autonomic load stimulation of the gong routine application (GRA) protocol versus the single routine (SR) protocol in Tai Chi to inform health promotion interventions.
results_summary: The GRA protocol showed lower autonomic load, reduced sympathetic activity, and higher parasympathetic activity compared to the SR protocol. The study suggests combining both protocols in Tai Chi instruction may enhance skills and health benefits.
population_specificity: Forty-five university students.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to outline the role of Tai Chi in preventing and managing hypertension.
results_summary: The abstract suggests Tai Chi may help alleviate hypertension risks, but no specific efficacy data or results are provided. The study highlights limitations of antihypertensive drugs and proposes Tai Chi as a potential alternative.
population_specificity: Not specified (general hypertension patients implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Tai Chi on the health-related quality of life (HRQoL) of people with neurodegenerative diseases.
results_summary: The meta-analysis of eight RCTs found that Tai Chi significantly improved HRQoL in patients with neurodegenerative diseases, particularly cognitive decline and Parkinson's disease, with low heterogeneity. However, the heterogeneity across interventions was relatively high, indicating variability in study designs or outcomes.
population_specificity: People with neurodegenerative diseases (cognitive decline or Parkinson's disease).
effective_dosage: Not specified (intervention duration ranged from 8 to 24 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of high-frequency, intensive multimodal training (including Tai Chi) in improving motor and cognitive function in patients with Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: The study found that 4 weeks of high-frequency Tai Chi therapy combined with cognitive and speech training significantly improved verbal and figural episodic memory, visuospatial function, gait, stability, and sleepiness in PD patients compared to a control group. Some benefits persisted at the 6-month follow-up.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with idiopathic Parkinson's disease (n=28, intervention group n=15, control group n=13).
effective_dosage: 2 weekly Tai Chi sessions over 4 weeks, combined with smartphone-based speech and cognitive training.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Tai Chi is effective in reducing fall rates among older adults.
results_summary: The study found that Tai Chi, along with other interventions, has been shown to reduce fall rates in older adults. It is listed as one of the effective methods for fall prevention.
population_specificity: Older adults at risk of falls due to factors like impaired balance, gait, or strength.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Montmorency tart cherry juice on quality of life and inflammatory markers in individuals with mild to moderate ulcerative colitis.
results_summary: The abstract describes the study protocol but does not report results, as the trial is ongoing.
population_specificity: 40 participants with mild to moderate ulcerative colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether Tai Chi reduces the rate of falls and the risk of falling in older adults living in the community.
results_summary: Tai Chi significantly reduced the risk of falling (RR 0.71, 95% CI 0.57 to 0.87) but the reduction in the rate of falls bordered on statistical significance (RaR 0.72, 95% CI 0.52 to 1.00).
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (65+ years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Tai Chi versus aerobic exercise in reducing systolic blood pressure (SBP) in adults with prehypertension.
results_summary: The study found that Tai Chi was more effective than aerobic exercise in reducing SBP at 6 and 12 months, as well as 24-hour and nighttime ambulatory SBP. The differences were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Adults aged 18-65 years with prehypertension (SBP 120-139 mm Hg and/or DBP 80-89 mm Hg).
effective_dosage: Four 60-minute supervised Tai Chi sessions per week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cost-effectiveness of Tai Chi as a falls prevention strategy for older adults.
results_summary: Tai Chi was found to be the most cost-effective falls prevention strategy for community-dwelling older people, with strong evidence supporting its efficacy. Other interventions like cataract surgery and psychotropic medication withdrawal were also cost-effective but had less certain effectiveness due to limited trials.
population_specificity: People aged 65 years and over living in the community and in residential aged-care facilities.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Tai Chi as an evidence-based fall prevention intervention for the elderly.
results_summary: The study found that participation in Tai Chi is an effective intervention for preventing falls in the elderly, alongside other multi-component exercises and environmental modifications. It was recommended as part of a multifactorial approach to fall prevention.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals at risk of falls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether Montmorency tart cherry juice could improve health-related quality of life and reduce symptoms in patients with mild to moderate ulcerative colitis compared to a placebo.
results_summary: Tart cherry juice significantly improved IBD-related quality of life (IBDQ) and reduced clinical colitis activity and fecal calprotectin levels compared to placebo, with high compliance and minimal adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate ulcerative colitis (N=35).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of tart cherry juice consumption on cardio-metabolic risk factors through a systematic review and meta-analysis of RCTs.
results_summary: Tart cherry juice significantly reduced fasting blood sugar levels, particularly in subgroups with specific conditions (e.g., age ≥ 40, BMI ≥ 30), but had no significant effect on cholesterol, triglycerides, blood pressure, or body composition. Some subgroup analyses showed minor effects on insulin and lipid profiles.
population_specificity: Participants in RCTs, with specific subgroups analyzed (e.g., age ≥ 40, BMI ≥ 30).
study_duration: Follow-up durations varied, with some studies lasting ≤ 4 weeks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how daily consumption of Montmorency tart cherry juice affects biomarkers of bone metabolism in older women.
results_summary: The higher dose of tart cherry juice (TC2X) significantly reduced a bone resorption marker but did not alter bone formation or turnover biomarkers. No changes in inflammation or oxidative stress markers were observed with either dose.
population_specificity: Healthy women aged 65-80 years (n = 27).
effective_dosage: ~240 mL (8 fl. oz.) once (TC1X) or twice (TC2X) per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether daily consumption of Montmorency tart cherry juice reduces the frequency of gout attacks in individuals with gout.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study is described as a proposed randomized clinical trial.
population_specificity: 120 individuals aged 18-80 years with a clinical diagnosis of gout and a self-reported gout flare in the previous year.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tart cherry juice could improve lipid profiles, blood pressure, glucose, insulin, and insulin resistance in older adults.
results_summary: Tart cherry juice significantly reduced systolic BP and LDL cholesterol but increased glucose, triglycerides, and BMI compared to the control. No significant changes were observed in body weight, HDL cholesterol, diastolic BP, insulin, or HOMA-IR.
population_specificity: 17 men and 20 women aged 65-80 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily consumption of tart cherry juice could improve cognitive abilities in older adults with normal cognitive function, potentially through its anti-oxidative, anti-inflammatory, and blood pressure-lowering properties.
results_summary: Tart cherry juice consumption improved subjective memory contentment, movement time, paired associates learning, visual sustained attention, and spatial working memory compared to baseline and control group. The effects were statistically significant for most measures.
population_specificity: Adults aged 65-80 with normal cognitive function (n=37).
effective_dosage: Two cups of Montmorency tart cherry juice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of tart cherry juice and pomegranate juice on markers of exercise-induced muscle damage in non-resistance trained men.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant differences between tart cherry juice, pomegranate juice, and placebo in improving recovery from eccentric exercise, as measured by muscle strength, soreness, creatine kinase levels, and range of motion.
population_specificity: Non-resistance trained men (age 24.0 (IQR 22.0, 33.0) years, BMI 25.6 ± 4.0 kg·m-2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tart cherry juice consumption affects blood biomarkers of inflammation and oxidative stress in older adults.
results_summary: Tart cherry juice significantly increased DNA repair activity and reduced CRP levels compared to the control group, with notable decreases in CRP, MDA, and OxLDL within the intervention group. The study suggests tart cherry juice's cardiovascular benefits may stem from its anti-oxidative and anti-inflammatory properties.
population_specificity: 37 men and women aged 65–80 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether Tart Cherry Juice (TCJ) reduces serum uric acid (sUA) concentrations and impacts lipidemia, glycemia, and inflammation in overweight and obese individuals at risk for gout and related comorbidities.
results_summary: TCJ significantly reduced sUA by 19.2% and showed trends in reducing proinflammatory markers, though no significant changes were observed in cardiovascular risk or insulin resistance markers.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese adults (BMI >25.0 kg/m²; n=26, 18 women/8 men, mean age 41±11 years).
study_duration: 4 weeks per intervention (TCJ or placebo), with a 4-week washout period between interventions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if tart cherry juice improves insomnia confirmed by polysomnography and whether tryptophan availability is a potential mechanism for this effect.
results_summary: Tart cherry juice increased sleep time by 84 minutes and improved sleep efficiency in elderly individuals with insomnia. It also reduced the kynurenine-to-tryptophan ratio and prostaglandin E2 levels, suggesting enhanced tryptophan availability and reduced inflammation.
population_specificity: Individuals older than 50 years with insomnia (excluding those with sleep apnea).
study_duration: 2 weeks per intervention (cherry juice and placebo), separated by a 2-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of tart cherry juice in reducing pain and other symptoms of knee osteoarthritis (OA) and its impact on inflammatory markers.
results_summary: Tart cherry juice significantly improved WOMAC scores and reduced hsCRP levels compared to placebo, but the difference between treatments was not statistically significant. Walking time, acetaminophen use, and plasma urate/creatinine levels were unaffected.
population_specificity: 58 non-diabetic patients with Kellgren grade 2-3 knee OA.
study_duration: 6 weeks per treatment period with a 1-week washout.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the dose-dependent effects of tart cherry juice on cellular processes like apoptosis, proliferation, and cell death in human breast cancer cells.
results_summary: Tart cherry juice showed a biphasic effect on apoptosis (increased at 3% but decreased at 1%) and reduced cellular proliferation at higher concentrations (≥10%), primarily through necrosis. No significant effect on proliferation was observed at lower concentrations (<10%).
population_specificity: MCF-7 human breast cancer cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a proprietary tart cherry juice blend improved subjective reports of insomnia compared to a placebo in older adults with chronic insomnia.
results_summary: The tart cherry juice showed statistically significant improvements in sleep variables, particularly reducing insomnia severity (minutes awake after sleep onset), but no significant improvements in sleep latency, total sleep time, or sleep efficiency compared to placebo. Effect sizes were moderate to negligible, suggesting modest benefits comparable to valerian and some melatonin studies but less effective than evidence-based treatments.
population_specificity: Older adults with chronic insomnia who were otherwise healthy.
study_duration: 2 weeks per treatment (with a 2-week washout period)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tart cherry juice, rich in anthocyanins, improves older adults' capacity to resist oxidative damage during acute oxidative stress.
results_summary: Tart cherry juice reduced oxidative damage markers (plasma F(2)-isoprostane and urinary oxidized nucleic acids) in response to stress, while placebo had no effect, suggesting enhanced antioxidant defenses in older adults.
population_specificity: 12 older adults (6 men, 6 women; aged 61-75 years).
study_duration: 14 days per intervention, with a 4-week washout between treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether a tart cherry juice blend could prevent symptoms of exercise-induced muscle damage, specifically strength loss, pain, muscle tenderness, and changes in relaxed elbow angle.
results_summary: Tart cherry juice significantly reduced strength loss and pain compared to placebo after eccentric exercise, with strength loss averaging 4% versus 22% for placebo. No significant differences were observed in muscle tenderness or relaxed elbow angle between the cherry juice and placebo trials.
population_specificity: Fourteen male college students

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different dosages and formulations (juice vs. capsule) of tart cherry on markers of inflammation and oxidative stress.
results_summary: Tart cherry ingestion transiently decreased uric acid (UA), with capsules showing longer-lasting effects than juice, but no significant changes were observed in hsCRP or ORAC. The effects on UA were not maintained with continued supplementation.
population_specificity: 48 participants randomly allocated to six treatment groups.
effective_dosage: 240 ml juice per bottle or 480 mg powdered capsule, administered once or twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Montmorency tart cherry juice on nitric oxide biomarkers, vascular function, and exercise performance in trained cyclists.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results regarding the effects of tart cherry juice on the measured outcomes.
population_specificity: 10 trained cyclists

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of tart cherry juice on recovery, inflammation, and oxidative stress in athletes, particularly during intense training or competition.
results_summary: Tart cherry juice was found to reduce pain, accelerate strength recovery, and lower blood markers of inflammation and oxidative stress after exercise. It may be most beneficial during recovery-focused phases rather than adaptation/build stages of training.
population_specificity: Athletes, particularly those engaged in strength and endurance exercise or intense training/competition.
effective_dosage: 8 to 12 oz twice a day (1 oz if concentrate form), with a 4- to 5-day loading phase before the event and 2 to 3 days after.
study_duration: Short-term, typically around 4-5 days before and 2-3 days after an event.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether tart cherry juice aids recovery and reduces muscle damage, inflammation, and oxidative stress in marathon runners.
results_summary: Tart cherry juice significantly improved isometric strength recovery, reduced inflammation markers (IL-6, CRP, uric acid), and increased total antioxidant status compared to placebo. It also lowered lipid peroxidation (TBARS) at 48 hours post-race, though protein carbonyls showed no difference.
population_specificity: Recreational marathon runners
study_duration: 5 days before, the day of, and 48 hours after the marathon

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the association between taurine levels and colorectal cancer (CRC) and its potential as a diagnostic metabolite.
results_summary: Taurine was significantly associated with increased odds of CRC and served as a discriminator for CRC diagnosis, particularly in blood samples. However, significant heterogeneity was noted in some outcomes.
population_specificity: Colorectal cancer patients (samples = 1714)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of taurine, alone and in combination with CBD, on inflammatory cytokines and periodontitis in an animal model.
results_summary: The combination of CBD and taurine significantly reduced inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-1β), TRAP+ cells, and resorbed pit areas, as well as improved periodontal health metrics like alveolar bone resorption and pocket depth.
population_specificity: Sprague-Dawley rats with P. gingivalis-induced periodontitis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (low- and high-dose CBD with taurine, but exact amounts not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if tart cherry juice blend (TCJB) could reduce muscle damage from exercise by decreasing inflammatory and oxidative stress responses in horses.
results_summary: TCJB administration was associated with lower serum AST activity compared to placebo, but had no effect on oxidative stress (TBARS) or inflammation (SAA) markers. The exercise protocol increased TBARS, SAA, and AST levels in all horses.
population_specificity: 6 horses

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine (TAU) could enhance the efficacy of artemisinin (ART) in treating Plasmodium berghei infection in mice by modulating the immune response.
results_summary: The study found that combining TAU with ART significantly reduced parasitaemia, prolonged survival, and decreased expression of inflammasome-related genes and inflammatory cytokines in infected mice, while also reducing spleen pathology.
population_specificity: Mice infected with Plasmodium berghei ANKA strain.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine could protect against irinotecan-induced muscle dysfunction by modulating oxidative and endoplasmic reticulum stress.
results_summary: Taurine pretreatment increased cell viability, reduced cytotoxicity, enhanced ROS clearance, and preserved myotube differentiation ability in human skeletal muscle cells exposed to irinotecan. It also mitigated irinotecan-induced endoplasmic reticulum stress markers (CHOP and GRP78).
population_specificity: Human skeletal muscle cells (HSkMCs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how taurine inhibits autophagy and induces iron apoptosis in hepatic stellate cells, and to propose a Tau-based therapy for liver fibrosis.
results_summary: Taurine interacts with key proteins to inhibit autophagy and promote iron apoptosis, and liposomal delivery systems are suggested as an effective method for Tau-based treatments.
population_specificity: Hepatic stellate cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antineoplastic efficacy of a taurine-derived carbon dots-ceria (CDs-CeO2) nanohybrid against human triple-negative mammary carcinoma cells.
results_summary: The nanohybrid demonstrated significant dose-dependent anticancer activity, inducing cell death likely due to increased reactive oxygen species (ROS) production. Molecular docking revealed strong binding affinity of CDs to proapoptotic and antiapoptotic proteins, suggesting a potential mechanism for its anticancer effects.
population_specificity: Human triple-negative mammary carcinoma cells (MDA-MB-231)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective potential of taurine against MTX-induced cardiotoxicity in rats, both alone and in combination with EMIQ.
results_summary: Taurine demonstrated significant protective effects against MTX-induced cardiotoxicity, showing antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and antiapoptotic properties. Combined treatment with half-doses of taurine and EMIQ offered superior protection compared to full doses of each agent alone.
population_specificity: Male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the physiological role of taurine in Japanese Black steers during different fattening phases and investigate its association with lipid and methionine metabolism.
results_summary: Plasma taurine and cholesterol concentrations significantly increased during the middle fattening phase (T2), correlating with changes in lipid and methionine metabolism. Gene expression related to taurine synthesis (CSAD, CDO1, CYP7A1) varied across phases, with oleate and propionate upregulating CDO1 in hepatocytes.
population_specificity: Japanese Black steers (Bos taurus) during early (13 mo), middle (20 mo), and late (28 mo) fattening phases.
study_duration: Not specified (sampled at three time points)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the differential effects of chronic and intermittent taurine administration on alcohol consumption and behavioral changes in adolescent and young adult rats subjected to binge drinking.
results_summary: Chronic taurine treatment did not alter alcohol consumption, while intermittent administration increased alcohol intake. No anxiolytic-like effects or changes in corticosterone or BDNF levels were observed.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (35 days old, adolescent and young adult).
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg, administered intraperitoneally daily or intermittently.
study_duration: 4 cycles of binge drinking (3 days per week for 2 hours each).
interactions: Increased alcohol intake when combined with intermittent taurine administration.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the frequency of bile acid malabsorption (BAM) using 75SeHCAT scintigraphy and assess the response to treatment with bile acid sequestrants.
results_summary: The study found that 46% of patients tested positive for BAM, with cholecystectomy and ileal resection as significant predictors. Treatment with bile acid binders was effective in 76% of cases.
population_specificity: 420 patients with chronic watery diarrhea who underwent 75SeHCAT scanning from January 2016 to January 2023.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether mitochondrial DNA mutations affect τm5U modification in hmtRNATrp and whether taurine supplementation could improve mitochondrial translation in affected cells.
results_summary: The study found that certain pathogenic mutations in hmtRNATrp caused τm5U hypomodification, and taurine supplementation improved mitochondrial translation in patient cells.
population_specificity: Patient cells with specific mitochondrial DNA mutations (e.g., m.5541C > T, m.5532G > A, m.5545C > T).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and validate a rapid, selective HPLC method for the simultaneous estimation of vinpocetine and its potential impurities in tablet formulations.
results_summary: The study successfully developed an HPLC method optimized using response surface methodology, demonstrating good selectivity, precision, linearity, and recovery. Significant degradation of vinpocetine was observed under acid and alkali hydrolysis conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory-based study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate Vinpocetine's protective effects against fluoxetine-induced liver damage in rats, focusing on its role in modulating PPAR-γ and Nrf2 pathways.
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly reduced fluoxetine-induced liver damage by lowering hepatotoxicity biomarkers, oxidative stress, and inflammation, while upregulating PPAR-γ expression and reversing apoptotic markers.
population_specificity: Rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine Vinpocetine's effects on aged pancreatic beta-cell functions and its potential to reduce oxidative stress and inflammation markers.
results_summary: Vinpocetine significantly increased insulin secretion in aged islets, reduced oxidative stress markers, and decreased expression of aging-related genes (P16, P38) and inflammatory markers (TNF-α, IL-6, NF-κB).
population_specificity: Aged rats with isolated pancreatic islet cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine Vinpocetine's modulatory effects on neurobehavioral comorbidities via the mTOR signaling pathway in a lithium-pilocarpine rat model of seizures.
results_summary: Vinpocetine showed a protective effect against seizures, improved locomotor and cognitive abilities, and exerted neuroprotective action by inhibiting hippocampal glutamate excitotoxicity, mTOR pathway, and inflammatory and apoptotic parameters.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced seizures using lithium-pilocarpine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether combining pomegranate with vinpocetine could provide a disease-modifying antiparkinsonian effect without adjuvant L-dopa.
results_summary: The combination of pomegranate and vinpocetine improved locomotor activities, cognition, neurotransmitter levels, and reduced oxidative stress and inflammatory markers in a rat model of parkinsonism. The effects were comparable to L-dopa treatment.
population_specificity: Rats with rotenone-induced parkinsonism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate Vinpocetine's role in Nrf2-mediated antioxidant protection against H2O2 and paracetamol-induced liver toxicity.
results_summary: Vinpocetine prevented cytotoxicity and ROS generation induced by H2O2 and APAP, increased Nrf2 and HO-1 expression, and stabilized Nrf2 by competing with Keap1 binding. It restored antioxidative/oxidative balance and may mitigate drug-induced liver injuries.
population_specificity: Normal human hepatic cell line (L02 cells)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether vinpocetine, a PDE1 inhibitor, could ameliorate ASD-related behavioral and biochemical phenotypes in a prenatal-valproic acid-induced rat model of autism.
results_summary: Vinpocetine improved social behavior, repetitive behavior, anxiety, locomotion, and nociception, while also enhancing neuronal function markers (BDNF, synapsin-IIa, DCX, pCREB/CREB), reducing inflammation (TNF-α, IL-6), and mitigating oxidative stress (TBARS, GSH) in key brain regions.
population_specificity: Prenatal-valproic acid-induced ASD model in rats.
